December 31 next following the date upon which they are issued. Licenses for
temporary places of amusement or for forms of itinerant amusement shall expire
at the time specified therein. Licenses issued for permanent places of
amusement under the provisions of this chapter may be renewed annually before
January 1, upon application made to the Clerk-Treasurer. The license required
herein shall be in addition to any and all licenses otherwise required by law.
705.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day's
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 715
Coin Operated Amusement Devices
715.01   Amusement device defined.

CROSS REFERENCES

715.01 AMUSEMENT DEVICE DEFINED.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the term "amusement or entertainment
device" means any type of shooter-type or flipper-type, kicker-type or bat-type
coin operated, instrument or equipment, or any electronic-type game device.
(Ord. 739. Passed 9-31-81.)
715.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association displaying for
public patronage or keeping for operation any amusement or entertainment
devices herein defined, shall be required to obtain a license therefor.
(Ord. 739. Passed 9-31-81.)
715.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE.
   Application for such license shall be made to the Clerk-Treasurer for that
purpose and the application for such license shall contain the following
information:
   (a)   Name, address, age, date and place of birth of the applicant.
   (b)   Address where the machine or device will be displayed or operated and
business conducted at that address.
   (c)   Description, mechanical features, name of manufacturer and serial
number of the machines covered by the license.
   (d)   Every applicant, before being granted a license shall pay the
following license fee for the privilege of maintaining or operating each such
amusement device. One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first device; two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second and third such device and five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each amusement device thereafter to be placed at such
address. The license shall be an annual license.
      (Ord. 739. Passed 9-31-81.)
715.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions herein, in addition to the revocation
of his license shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. If the
offender has previously been convicted of a violation herein, any subsequent
violation shall be a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 739. Passed 9-31-81.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 725
Peddlers and Itinerant Vendors
725.01   Definitions.
725.02   License required.
725.03   Application.
725.04   Investigation and issuance.
725.05   Fees.
725.06   Relation to interstate commerce; establishing fees.
725.07   Exhibition of license.
725.08   Duty of police to enforce.
725.09   Revocation of license.
725.10   Appeal.
725.11   Expiration of license.
725.12   Limitations on soliciting.
725.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R. C. 715.46
Power to regulate - see Ohio R. C. 715.61 et seq.
Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R. C. 1345.21 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 1716
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R. C. 3715.51 et seq.
Trespass - see GEN. OFF.
537.06
725.01 DEFINITIONS.
   "Itinerant canvasser" or "solicitor" means any individual or group traveling
from place to place attempting to take orders for sale of merchandise or
services of any nature.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-10-00.)
725.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No itinerant canvasser or solicitor, as defined in Section
725.01, shall engage in any business within the Village without first obtaining
a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. This
section shall not apply to any itinerant canvasser or solicitor that is, or is
soliciting or canvassing on behalf of, a political subdivision of this state or
a not-for-profit organization having a charitable, civic, cultural, educational
or similar community purpose.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-10-00.)
725.03 APPLICATION.
   Applicants for a license under this chapter must file with the Clerk-
Treasurer a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be
furnished by the Clerk-Treasurer which shall give the following information:
   (a)   Name and description of the applicant;
   (b)   Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant;
   (c)   A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods or
services to be sold;
   (d)   If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with
credentials establishing the exact relationship;
   (e)   The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
   (f)   If goods or property is being offered for sale, the place where the
goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for sale thereof, are
manufactured or produced, where the goods or products are located at the time
the application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery;
   (g)   If services are being offered for purchase or hire, the identity of
each person, company or other entity who or which will actually provide such
services, along with a copy of all licenses permitting each such person,
company or other entity to offer and perform such services;
   (h)   If the vending is take place from a fixed location, evidence of the
property owner’s permission to the applicant allowing such vending;
   (i)   The days of the week and the hours during each day that the applicant
requests to perform the soliciting or canvassing;
   (j)   A recent photograph of the applicant and of each agent who will
participate in the soliciting or canvassing;
   (k)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant or agents has been
convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance,
the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor.
   At the time of filing the application, a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall
be paid to the Clerk- Treasurer to cover the cost of investigation of the facts
stated therein.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-10-00.)
 
725.04 INVESTIGATION AND ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Upon receipt of the application the Clerk-Treasurer shall refer the
matter to the Mayor who may, in his discretion, cause an investigation of the
applicant's business and moral character to be made if he so deems it necessary
for the protection of the public welfare.
   (b)   In the event the applicant's character or business responsibility is
found to be unsatisfactory, then no license shall be issued. The result of the
investigation shall be shown upon the application form.
   (c)   If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business
responsibility of the application are found to be satisfactory, such shall be
endorsed upon the application and the license shall be issued by the Clerk as
hereinafter set forth.
725.05 FEES.
   The license fee which shall be charged by the Clerk-Treasurer for the
license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for ten days or less and fifty
dollars ($50.00) for any longer period not to exceed a year.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-10-00.)
725.06 RELATION TO INTERSTATE COMMERCE; ESTABLISHING FEES.
   (a)   None of the license fees provided for by this chapter shall be so
applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case
where a license fee is believed by a licensee or applicant for a license to
place an undue burden upon such commerce, he may apply to the Mayor for an
adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable or
unfair as to such commerce. The application may be made before, at or within
six months after payment of the prescribed license fee. The applicant shall, by
affidavit and supporting testimony, show his method of business and such other
information as the Mayor may deem necessary in order to determine the extent,
if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. The Mayor shall then conduct an
investigation, comparing the applicant's business with other businesses of like
nature and shall make findings of fact from which he shall determine whether
the fee fixed by this chapter is unfair, unreasonable or discriminatory as to
the applicant's business and shall fix as the license fee for the applicant, an
amount that is fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory or, if the fee has
already been paid, shall order a refund of the amount over and above the fee so
fixed.
   (b)   In fixing the fee to be charged, the Mayor shall have the power to
base the fee upon a percentage of gross sales, or any other method which will
assure that the fee assessed shall be uniform with that assessed on businesses
of like nature, so long as the amount assessed does not exceed the fees as
prescribed in Section
725.05. Should the Mayor determine the gross sales measure of the fee to be the
fair basis, he may require the applicant to submit, either at the time of
termination of the applicant's business in the Village or at the end of the
amount of fee therefor, provided that no additional fee during any one calendar
year shall be required after the licensee has paid an amount equal to the
annual license as prescribed in Section
725.05.
725.07 EXHIBITION OF LICENSE.
   Solicitors and canvassers are required to exhibit their licenses at the
request of any citizen.
725.08 DUTY OF POLICE TO ENFORCE.
   It shall be the duty of any police officer of the Village to require any
person seen soliciting or canvassing, and who is not known by the officer to be
duly licensed, to produce his solicitor's or canvasser's license and to enforce
the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the
same.
725.09 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by
the Mayor after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes:
      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for license;
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of
carrying on his business as solicitor or as canvasser;
      (3)   Any violation of this chapter;
      (4)   conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude;
or
      (5)   Conducting the business of soliciting, or of canvassing, in an
unlawful manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a
menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public.
 
   (b)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and
place of hearing. The notice shall be served personally upon the person or
mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at the last known address at least
five days prior to the date set for hearing.
725.10 APPEAL.
   Any person aggrieved by the action of the Chief of Police or the Clerk-
Treasurer in the denial of a license as provided in Section
725.04 or the action of the Mayor in the assessing of the fee as provided in
Section
725.06 shall have the right of appeal to Council. The appeal shall be taken by
filing with Council, within fourteen days after notice of the action complained
of has been mailed to the person's last known address, a written statement
setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal and notice of the hearing shall
be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in Section
725.09 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of Council
on the appeal shall be final and conclusive.
725.11 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire
on December 31 in the year when issued. All other licenses shall expire on the
date specified in the license.
725.12 LIMITATIONS ON SOLICITING.
   (a)   No soliciting or canvassing shall be permitted Monday through Friday
before 9:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m. or on Saturday and Sunday before 9:00 a.m.
or after 4:00 p.m.
   (b)   Any person, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peaceably
depart from premises when requested to do so by any occupant of a residence. If
a residence or business is posted with a notice which states “No Solicitations”
or “No Solicitors Permitted” or similar wording, a canvasser or solicitor shall
immediately and peaceably depart the premises.
   (c)   No person shall sell, offer for sale, hawk, peddle, canvass or vend
any goods, produce or services of any kind upon the streets or highways of the
Village or in the rights of way thereto.
   (d)   No itinerant canvasser or solicitor shall park any vehicle upon any of
the streets or highways of the Village or in the rights of way thereto in order
to sort, re-arrange or clean any of the vendor’s goods or produce or deposit
any refuse on any streets, highways or rights of way thereto.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-10-00.)
725.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty
of a minor misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 735
Video Service Providers
735.01   Fee.
 
735.01 FEE.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of three percent (3.0%) to the video service provider’s
gross revenues as defined in Ohio R.C. 1332.32(B).
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the Village of New Middletown on a quarterly basis but not sooner
than forty-five days not later than sixty days after the end of each calendar
quarter.
   (c)   The Village is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage as determined by this Village
Council above, which notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of
notice from such video service provider that it will begin providing video
service in the Village pursuant to a State-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 2008-01. Passed 1-14-08.)

311.01
901.01 STREET GRADES.
   The grades upon the streets of the Village shall be as shown by street maps
on file with the Clerk-Treasurer and made a part hereof.
901.02 STREET NAMES.
   The streets of the Village shall be named and known as shown by the official
map on file with the Clerk-Treasurer and made a part hereof.
901.03 WIDTHS.
   (a)   The streets of the Village shall be of the width shown by the official
map on file with the Clerk-Treasurer and made a part hereof.
 
   (b)   The width of all sidewalks in the Village shall be not less than four
feet.
901.04 STREET MARKING.
   The names of all streets, avenues, squares, parks, lanes and alleys in the
Village shall be legibly marked at the corners thereof, which shall be done by
and at the expense of the Village.
901.05 SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   The material of all sidewalks hereafter laid, constructed or repaired in the
Village shall be brick, stone, concrete, amiesite or any approved hard surface
paving material.
901.06 HOUSE NUMBERING PLAN.
   (a)   All entrances to buildings in the Village which front upon any of the
streets, avenues, squares, parks, alleys or lanes therein shall be legibly
numbered and in full view of the streets, the numbers to be placed above, or in
close proximity to the entrance by the owners thereof or their agents.
 
   (b)   The plan now on file with the Clerk-Treasurer is approved and
determined to be for the placing or numbering of the houses on the various
streets in the Village. Property owners or their agents may obtain their
numbers from this plan and be controlled thereby.
 
   (c)   Upon the failure of any owner of a building in the Village to comply
with the foregoing provisions within such time as Council shall determine, or
may at any time determine, Council may have the numbering required to be done
at the expense of such owner. Such numbers shall be furnished by Council and
the Clerk-Treasurer shall certify to the County Auditor all sums unpaid in this
connection on September 1 of each year to be placed by the Auditor on the
County tax duplicate as a lien on the lot or lands upon which buildings are
situated. Such sums shall be collected as other assessments are collected.
 
   (d)   No person shall willfully obstruct or interfere with any person
employed by Council to place the name of streets, avenues, squares, parks,
alleys or lanes, at the corners thereof, unlawfully obstruct or interfere with
any person employed by Council to place numbers on buildings as hereinbefore
provided or tear down or deface the same.
901.07 SHADE TREES.
   (a)   Shade trees planted in the streets of the Village shall be set at
points equi-distant from the curb line and the line of the sidewalk next to the
curb, provided that poplar trees shall not be planted in any such streets.
 
   (b)   No person shall cut down or mutilate any shade tree for any purpose
without the consent of Council.
901.08 CLEANING AND REPAIRING SIDEWALKS.
   (a)   No owner of any lot or land abutting upon any street shall refuse,
fail or neglect to repair or keep in repair and free from nuisance and
obstructions, the sidewalk in front of such lot or land after due notice of a
resolution of Council ordering the repair of such sidewalk, the removal of such
obstruction or the abatement of such nuisance.
 
   (b)   If the owner or person having charge of such land fails to comply with
such notice, Council shall cause the sidewalks to be repaired. All expenses and
labor costs incurred shall, when approved by Council, be paid out of Municipal
funds not otherwise appropriated. Council shall make a written return to the
County Auditor of their action, with a statement of the charges for their
services, the amount paid for labor, the fees of the officers serving such
notices, and a proper description of the premises. Such amounts, when allowed,
shall be entered upon the tax duplicate and be a lien upon such lands from and
after the date of the entry and be collected as other taxes and returned to the
Municipality with the General Fund.
901.09 SIDEWALKS TO BE CLEANED OF ICE AND SNOW.
   It shall be the duty of the owner of each and every parcel of real estate in
the Municipality abutting upon any sidewalk to keep such sidewalk abutting his
premises free and clear of snow and ice, and to remove therefrom all snow and
ice accumulated thereon within a reasonable time, which will ordinarily not
exceed twelve hours after the abatement of any storm during which any snow and
ice may have accumulated.
901.10 UNLOADING ON STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   No person shall unload any heavy material in the streets or sidewalks of the
Municipality by throwing or letting the same fall upon the pavement of any
street, sidewalk or other public way, without first placing some sufficient
protection over the pavement.
901.11 MATERIALS ON STREET OR SIDEWALK.
   No person shall encumber any street or sidewalk or, being the owner,
occupant or person having care of any building or lot of land bordering on any
street or sidewalk, permit the same to be encumbered with barrels, boxes, cans,
articles or substances of any kind, so as to interfere with the free and
unobstructed use thereof.
901.12 PROTECTING SIDEWALKS.
   In the transportation of any goods, materials or equipment across any
sidewalk in the Municipality, sufficient temporary planking shall be used to
protect such sidewalks from breakage. Such temporary planking shall be removed
at the close of each working day and the surface of the sidewalk immediately
cleaned and left in a passable condition.
901.13 MERCHANDISE DISPLAYS.
   No person shall use any street or sidewalk area, including the lateral strip
between the street and sidewalk, for the display of merchandise or for any
advertising display without the written permission of the Mayor.
901.14 REMOVAL OF LANTERNS AND WARNING BARRICADES.
   The removal of red lanterns, barricades or other means placed on the streets
and on construction projects, whether public or private, in the Municipality as
a warning or protection for the public by persons unauthorized to remove the
same, or the willful, careless or negligent destruction of such lanterns or
barricades is hereby prohibited.
901.15 WALKING OR RIDING OF HORSES ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall walk or ride a horse upon any sidewalk within the Village.
901.16 INSTALLATION OF DRAINAGE PIPE.
   (a)   No resident of the Village shall install a drainage pipe or system on
his/her property without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the
Village Administrator. The application for such permit shall be provided by the
Village Administrator on forms adopted by the Administration and shall include
all information which the Village Administrator deems appropriate including:
      (1)   Name and address of applicant;
      (2)   A drawing of where any drainage line or system is to be installed;
      (3)   A description of the type of material to be used in the drainage
project and such further facts as the Village Administrator deems appropriate;
      (4)   A five dollar ($5.00) application fee.
   (b)   Upon receipt of the application for such permit and the payment of the
five dollar ($5.00) application fee, the Administrator shall notify the
applicant in writing of the approval or denial of said permit.
   (c)   Whoever violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 1995-7. Passed 11-13-95.)
901.17 UNDERGROUND UTILITY LINES REQUIRED.
   All electric, telephone or cable lines hereinafter placed within the Village
of New Middletown must be laid underground.
(Ord. 1998-3. Passed 3-9-98.)
901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter where not otherwise provided
shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 903
Excavation Permits
903.01   Permit for street and sidewalk openings; bond.
903.02   Refilling; final inspection.
903.03   Red lights at excavations, obstructions of building materials.
903.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Establishment and care of streets - see Ohio R. C. 715.19, 717.01, 723.01
Openings by the Municipality - see Ohio R. C. 723.02
Changing established grade - see Ohio R. C. 723.03
Excavation liability - see Ohio R. C. 723.49 et seq.
Compulsory service connections - see Ohio R. C. 729.06, 743.23, 743.37
Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see Ohio R. C. 5589.10
903.01 PERMIT FOR STREET AND SIDEWALK OPENINGS; BOND.
      Permission may be granted to such persons as may desire to open up or
remove any portion of any street surface, curb, gutter, sidewalk or area
located between the sidewalk and gutter, provided that the consent of the
Village Administrator is first obtained and the necessity of such work is
established to his satisfaction. The Village Administrator shall adopt rules
and regulations outlining the requirements for obtaining a permit. A permit fee
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be collected by the Fiscal Officer for
such permit, and the applicant shall deposit moneys or a suitable bond
simultaneously with the issuance of such permit as a guarantee that the street
surface, curb, gutter, sidewalk or area located between the sidewalk and the
gutter shall be satisfactorily restored, such deposit or bond being deposited
with the Fiscal Officer in a sum of money as set forth in rules and regulations
adopted by the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 2020-09. Passed 1-11-21.)
903.02 REFILLING; FINAL INSPECTION.
   All street surfaces, curbs, gutters, sidewalks or area located between the
sidewalk and the gutter opened up, removed or damaged shall be replaced and
repaired by such permittee under supervision of any to the satisfaction of the
Village Administrator. The Village Administrator shall adopt rules and
regulations outlining the requirements for all work to be performed by
permittees in replacing and repairing Village streets and rights of way. Upon
completion of the work, the permittee shall notify the Village Administrator of
the fact of its completion and he shall make a final inspection thereof. If
such inspection is to the satisfaction of the Village Administrator, he shall
so notify the permittee and also the Fiscal Officer, who shall thereupon return
the guarantee deposit or release the bond. If the inspection discloses a defect
or unsatisfactory work that is unacceptable to the Village Administrator, he
shall notify the licensee of such defect or condition and the licensee shall
have ten days in which to rectify the same or forfeit the guarantee deposit or
bond, and the Village shall thereupon complete the repair or replacement at the
cost and expense of the permittee. If the permittee is the owner of the
property adjacent to the street, curb, gutter, sidewalk or right of way for
which the excavation permit was issued, and if such permittee fails to
reimburse the Village within thirty days after the mailing of a notice of the
costs for the repair or replacement, such amount shall be certified to the
County Auditor for collection of the same as other taxes and assessments are
collected.
(Ord. 2020-09. Passed 1-11-21.)
903.03 RED LIGHTS AT EXCAVATIONS, OBSTRUCTIONS OF BUILDING MATERIALS.
   Every person in this Village who digs or causes to be dug in or adjoining
any of the public ways of the Village any excavation whatsoever and every
person who occupies or causes to be occupied any portion of any public street
with building material or any obstruction, shall cause sufficient red lights to
be securely and conspicuously placed in or near such excavation, building
material or obstruction, one at each end of the space so excavated or occupied.
(Ord. 2020-09. Passed 1-11-21.)
903.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense. Each day's violation shall constitute a
separate offense. The second and subsequent offenses stemming from a second or
subsequent excavation shall be deemed a fourth degree misdemeanor.
(Ord. 2020-09. Passed 1-11-21.)

CHAPTER 921
Garbage Collection
921.01   Containers required.
921.02   Spillage prohibited.
921.03   Burning prohibited.
921.04   Definitions.
921.05   Rubbish and garbage collection.
921.06   Regulations for licensed collectors; fees.
921.07   Authorized collectors only.
921.08   Free day collection annually.
921.09   Customers responsible for charges.
921.10   Identification required on trash collection vehicles.
921.99      Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R. C. 715.43, 717.01
Employment of scavengers - see Ohio R. C. 3707.39
Disposal and transportation on public ways - see Ohio R. C. 3767.20 et seq.
Vehicle loads dropping, shifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
921.01 CONTAINERS REQUIRED.
   (a)   Every person within the Village responsible for the existence of
garbage, offal or other refuse matter shall provide and maintain upon the
premises where the same is produced a watertight galvanized iron receptacle of
not less than ten-gallon nor more than thirty-gallon capacity, with a suitable
cover of the same material for the reception of all offal, garbage and refuse
matter.
   (b)   The person providing and maintaining such receptacle shall keep the
same clean and disinfected at all times, covered and in good repair in such a
way as to prevent the same and its contents from becoming offensive, noxious or
dangerous to the health of the inhabitants of the Village.
   (c)   Such receptacles containing garbage shall at no time be placed at or
near the front of any building in the Village for the purpose of collection or
otherwise.
921.02 SPILLAGE PROHIBITED.
   The trucks or any other conveyances employed in the collection and
transportation of garbage shall be constructed with bodies that are watertight
and with tight covers or lids of the same material so as to effectually prevent
the scattering, spilling or leaking of the contents.
921.03 BURNING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall collect and burn any garbage of any kind upon any private
property and/or territory or public ground within the Municipality.
921.04 DEFINITIONS.
   In the interpretation of this chapter, the following words and phrases,
unless the context show another sense to be intended, shall have the following
meanings:
   (a)   "Garbage", "offal" or other "refuse matter" consists of every
accumulation of animal, vegetable and other matter than attends the
preparation, consumption, decay or dealing in or storage of meats, fish, fowls,
birds, fruits or vegetables, but does not include fish water or waste matter.
   (b)   "Rubbish" consists of wood, leaves, grass cuttings, weeds, dead trees,
or the branches thereof, chips, shavings, sawdust, woodenware, dodgers, printed
matter, papers, pasteboard, brass, rags, straw, boots, shoes, hats and all
other combustible matter, not included in this section under the term "garbage"
as defined in subsection (a) hereof.
   (c)   "Waste matter" consists of natural soil, earth, sand, clay, gravel,
loam, manure, stones, bricks, brickbats, plaster, Portland cement, crockery,
queensware, glass, glassware, ashes, cinders, shells, metals and all other
noncombustible materials.
   (d)   "Commercial or industrial garbage or waste" means all industrial
garbage or waste capable of incineration or burning that accumulates in, upon
or about the land and buildings, appurtenant to the business and activities of
breweries, wholesale produce and grocery dealers, meat packing and meat
wholesale dealers and fat rendering and hide processing plants.
      (Ord. 1990-8. Passed 4-25-91.)
921.05 RUBBISH AND GARBAGE COLLECTION.
   (a)   The Village Fiscal Officer is authorized, empowered and directed to
issue licenses for the collection of garbage and rubbish from commercial
establishments throughout the Village. The Village may enter into garbage and
rubbish collection after the termination of all outstanding licenses which can
take effect only after a thirty day written notice of termination.
   (b)   The Village Administrator is authorized and directed to prepare
specifications and with the consent of the Village Council, to authorize the
issuance of a franchise to a person, firm, or corporation, after advertising
and receiving bids as required by law, for the collection, transportation, and
disposal of rubbish material, refuse and garbage from residences on dedicated
streets within the Village for a period not to exceed five (5) years, subject
to any other provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   The franchise shall entitle the holder to be the only collector of
rubbish material, refuse and garbage for hire from all residences within the
Village which have curbside collection on a dedicated street.
   (d)   A franchise may be terminated by the Mayor, with the consent of the
Village Council if any franchise fails to comply with the provisions of this
chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated by the Director of Service.
   (e)   Collection of rubbish material, refuse and garbage from residential
property on dedicated streets by any person or firm or corporation not
authorized to do so pursuant to this chapter is prohibited. (Ord. 2020-03.
Passed 7-13-20.)
921.06 REGULATIONS FOR LICENSED COLLECTORS; FEES.
   All individuals, companies, partnerships or corporations seeking a license
to collect garbage and rubbish, including any recipient of a franchise issued
under Section
921.05 of the Codified Ordinances, must meet the following regulations:
   (a)   All must show ownership or have a notarized statement from an
equipment company that he will put into effect suitable equipment purchased,
being purchased or leased conforming to this specification. All equipment
utilized shall be cleaned at sufficient frequencies to prevent odor, nuisance
or insect breeding and shall be maintained in good order. Such equipment must
be of the packer type with all steel enclosed boxes and must be watertight. The
person must show the number of trucks he will use.
   (b)   All collectors of garbage and rubbish must assume the full
responsibility of disposal of garbage and rubbish. Charges for license fees for
garbage and rubbish collection shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year.
Such licenses as issued shall be subject to revocation in the event such
collector violates any of the regulations. Notice of revocation must be served
upon the licensee or collector in writing five days prior to revocation. Such
collector or licensee shall have the right to have a hearing on any matter
which is the cause for his license revocation. Such hearing shall be conducted
by the Mayor.
   (c)   Garbage must be picked up from all homes contracted in the Village at
least weekly or in accordance with the schedule or agreement made between the
collector and any commercial or industrial business.
   (d)   Collectors entering into contracts with commercial or industrial
business places in the Village must be able to furnish containers if such
containers are required and such collectors must be able to service such
containers daily, if necessary. Such containers must be portable, with a
minimum capacity of one to twenty cubic yards, all steel welded construction,
watertight doors or lids of such construction as to make the containers vermin
proof. Such containers shall be maintained and kept closed.
   (e)   Collections must be made between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.;
no collections on Sunday except in the case of an emergency, in which instance
collection may be made at the direction of the Mayor or the Fiscal Officer.
   (f)   An individual or company must carry property damage and public
liability insurance so as to free the Village from any liability. This
insurance must be in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000),
and a certificate of insurance must be deposited with the Clerk of the Village.
   (g)   An individual or company must file charges made for collection with
the Fiscal Officer and cannot make changes without the consent of the Fiscal
Officer. Prepaid charges shall not be made for a period longer than three
months.
   (h)   These regulations will be enforced by the Village Administrator.
   (i)   All license holders shall make their own collections.
   (j)   Licenses shall be issued by the Fiscal Officer upon payment of the
license fee as provided in subsection (b) hereof.
   (k)   If, during the time of the license period, there is any change in
company status or ownership, it shall be reported to the Fiscal Officer.
      (Ord. 2020-03. Passed 7-13-20.)
921.07 AUTHORIZED COLLECTORS ONLY.
   No person, firm, partnership or corporation except the duly authorized
garbage and rubbish collectors shall use the streets of the Village for the
purpose of collecting, transporting or disposing of any garbage and rubbish or
refuse.
(Ord. 1990-8. Passed 4-25-91.)
921.08 FREE DAY COLLECTION ANNUALLY.
   (a)   As part of the license issued annually, each firm, corporation,
association or individual shall grant the Village and its customers one free
day collection, which collection shall be carried out by each licensed operator
giving it or their customers proper notice as to the date and hours of
collection. This one day pickup shall take place on the first Saturday of May
of any given year. All pickups shall take place at the curb.
 
   (b)   Each license issued after the effective date of this section shall
spell out and define the intentions of this section.
 
   (c)   However, any company that provides unlimited pickup and including
solid waste pickup weekly can be excused from the spring pickup.
(Ord. 1990-8. Passed 4-25-91.)
921.09 CUSTOMERS RESPONSIBLE FOR CHARGES.
   (a)   Village Liability. The Village will not pay for any portion of the
total costs chargeable to each customer or home in the Village being serviced
by the collection of rubbish and garbage by the duly licensed collectors.
 
   (b)   Regulations.
      (1)   Each collector shall certify under oath the names of all customers
or homes together with addresses being serviced and the charges being made for
such service.
      (2)   This list shall be forwarded to the Clerk of the Village who must
confirm the same as to proper charges and the Clerk shall determine its
accuracy.
      (3)   The Village reserves the right to inspect all lists being
maintained by licensed collectors.
      (4)   Payment shall be made either on a monthly or quarterly basis.
      (5)   It is understood that the Village assumes no obligation whatsoever;
the Village shall be held harmless against any claims whatsoever either for
personal or property damage arising out of such collections and the Village
does not guarantee the payment of any account.
      (6)   During the term of any license period, no increases shall be made
by the licensed collectors.
         (Ord. 1990-8. Passed 4-25-91.)
921.10 IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED ON TRASH COLLECTION VEHICLES.
   All trash collection vehicles authorized to operate in the Village shall
display on both doors the name of the company in lettering at least six inches
high, phone number and/or address.
(Ord. 1990-8. Passed 4-25-91.)
 
921.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation which violates this chapter or any rule or
regulation promulgated by the Village Administrator or the Fiscal Officer with
regards to residential or commercial trash collection is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense. The second and subsequent offenses within
one year of conviction of the first offense shall be deemed a fourth degree
misdemeanor.
(Ord. 2020-03. Passed 7-13-20.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 923
Storm Sewers Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination
923.01   Purpose and scope.
923.02   Applicability.
923.03   Definitions.
923.04   Disclaimer of liability.
923.05   Conflicts, severability, nuisances and responsibility.
923.06   Responsibility for administration/storm water management plan.
923.07   Discharge and connection prohibitions.
923.08   Monitoring of illicit discharges and illegal connections.
923.09   Enforcement.
923.10   Remedies not exclusive.
 
923.01 PURPOSE AND SCOPE.
   The purpose of these regulations is to provide for the health, safety, and
general welfare of the citizens of the Village of New Middletown through the
regulation of illicit discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system
(MS4). The objectives of these regulations are:
   (a)   To prohibit illicit discharges and illegal connections to the MS4.
   (b)   To establish legal authority to carry out inspections, monitoring
procedures, and enforcement actions necessary to ensure compliance with this
regulation.
      (Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.02 APPLICABILITY.
   This regulation shall apply to all residential, commercial, industrial, or
institutional facilities responsible for discharges to the MS4 and on any lands
in New Middletown Village except for those discharges generated by the
activities detailed in Section
923.07(a)(1) to (a)(3) of this regulation. (Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.03 DEFINITIONS.
   The words and terms used in this regulation, unless otherwise expressly
stated, shall have the following meaning:
   (a)   Best Management Practices (BMPs): means schedules of activities,
prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution
prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other
management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants to storm
water. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and
practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal,
or drainage from raw materials storage.
   (b)   Village: means New Middletown Village, its designated representatives,
boards, or commissions.
   (c)   Environmental Protection Agency or United States Environmental
Protection Agency (USEPA): means the United States Environmental Protection
Agency, including but not limited to the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency
(Ohio EPA), or any duly authorized official of said agency.
   (d)   Floatable Material:  in general this term means any foreign matter
that may float or remain suspended in the water column, and includes but is not
limited to, plastic, aluminum cans, wood products, bottles, and paper products.
   (e)   Hazardous Material: means any material including any substance, waste,
or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or
physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly
contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health,
safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored,
transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed.
   (f)   Illicit Discharge: as defined at 40 C.F.R. 122.26 (b)(2) means any
discharge to an MS4 that is not composed entirely of storm water, except for
those discharges to an MS4 pursuant to a NPDES permit or noted in Section
923.07 of this regulation.
   (g)   Illegal Connection: means any drain or conveyance, whether on the
surface or subsurface, that allows an illicit discharge to enter the MS4.
   (h)   Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4): as defined at 40 C.F.R.
122.26 (b)(8), municipal separate storm sewer system means a conveyance or
system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal
streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, man-made channels, or storm
drains):
      (1)   Owned or operated by a State, city, town, borough, county, parish,
district, municipality, township, district, association, or other public body
(created by or pursuant to State law) having jurisdiction over sewage,
industrial wastes, including special districts under State law such as a sewer
district, or similar entity, or an Indian tribe or an authorized Indian tribal
organization, or a designated and approved management agency under section 208
of the Clean Water Act that discharges to waters of the United States;
      (2)   Designed or used for collecting or conveying storm water
      (3)   Which is not a combined sewer; and
      (4)   Which is not part of a Publicly Owned Treatment Works (POTW) as
defined at 40 C.F.R. 122.2.
   (i)   National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Storm Water
Discharge Permit:  means a permit issued by EPA (or by a State under authority
delegated pursuant to 33 USC §1342(b)) that authorizes the discharge of
pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on
an individual, group, or general area-wide basis.
   (j)   Off-Lot Discharging Home Sewage Treatment System: means a system
designed to treat home sewage on-site and discharges treated wastewater
effluent off the property into a storm water or surface water conveyance or
system.
   (k)   Owner/Operator: means any individual, association, organization,
partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as
either the owner or on the owner's behalf.
   (l)   Pollutant: means anything that causes or contributes to pollution.
Pollutants may include, but are not limited to, paints, varnishes, solvents,
oil and other automotive fluids, non-hazardous liquid and solid wastes, yard
wastes, refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter or other discarded or abandoned
objects, floatable materials, pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, hazardous
materials, wastes, sewage, dissolved and particulate metals, animal wastes,
residues that result from constructing a structure, and noxious or offensive
matter of any kind.
   (m)   Storm Water: means any surface flow, runoff or any drainage consisting
entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation.
   (n)   Wastewater: means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint
of a source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes
from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions.
      (Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.04 DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY.
   Compliance with the provisions of this regulation shall not relieve any
person from responsibility for damage to any person otherwise imposed by law.
The provisions of this regulation are promulgated to promote the health,
safety, and welfare of the public and are not designed for the benefit of any
individual or for the benefit of any particular parcel of property.
(Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.05 CONFLICTS, SEVERABILITY, NUISANCES AND RESPONSIBILITY.
   (a)   Where this regulation is in conflict with other provisions of law or
ordinance, the most restrictive provisions, as determined by the Village, shall
prevail.
   (b)   If any clause, section, or provision of this regulation is declared
invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, the validity
of the remainder shall not be affected thereby.
   (c)   This regulation shall not be construed as authorizing any person to
maintain a nuisance on their property, and compliance with the provisions of
this regulation shall not be a defense in any action to abate such a nuisance.
   (d)   Failure of the Village to observe or recognize hazardous or unsightly
conditions or to recommend corrective measures shall not relieve the site owner
from the responsibility for the condition or damage resulting therefrom, and
shall not result in the Village, its officers, employees, or agents being
responsible for any condition or damage resulting therefrom.
(Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.06 RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION/STORM WATER MANAGEMENT PLAN.
   (a)   The Village shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of
this regulation. The Village may contract with the Mahoning County Board of
Health or another entity to conduct inspections and monitoring and to assist
with enforcement actions.
   (b)   The Village, under the direction of the Mayor, shall establish and
implement a Storm Water Management Program for the Village. The Mayor may
establish a Village Storm Water Management Program (SWMP) Citizens Committee,
which shall be composed of volunteers from the Village and other interested
persons. The members of the SWMP Citizens Committee shall be designated by the
Mayor. The SWMP Citizens Committee shall be responsible for assisting the Mayor
and the Village in establishing, evaluating and implementing the Village's
SWMP.
(Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.07 DISCHARGE AND CONNECTION PROHIBITIONS.
   (a)   Prohibition of Illicit Discharges. No person shall discharge, or cause
to be discharged, an illicit discharge into the MS4. The commencement, conduct,
or continuance of any illicit discharge to the MS4 is prohibited except as
described below:
      (1)   Water line flushing; landscape irrigation; diverted stream flows;
rising ground waters; uncontaminated ground water infiltration; uncontaminated
pumped ground water; discharges from potable water sources; foundation drains;
air conditioning condensate; irrigation water; springs; water from crawl space
pumps; footing drains; lawn watering; individual residential car washing; flows
from riparian habitats and wetlands; dechlorinated swimming pool discharges;
street wash water; and discharges or flows from fire fighting activities. These
discharges are exempt until such time as they are determined by the Village to
be significant contributors of pollutants to the MS4.
      (2)   Discharges specified in writing by the Village as being necessary
to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the community.
      (3)   Discharges from off-lot discharging home sewage treatment systems
permitted by the Mahoning County Board of Health or Mahoning County Sanitary
Engineer for the purpose of discharging treated sewage effluent in accordance
with Ohio Administrative Code 3701-29-02(6) until such time as the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency issues an NPDES permitting mechanism for
residential 1, 2, or 3 family dwellings. These discharges are exempt unless
such discharges are deemed to be creating a public health nuisance by the
Mahoning County Board of Health or the Mahoning County Sanitary Engineer. In
compliance with the Village's Storm Water Management Program, discharges from
all off-lot discharging home sewage treatment systems must either be eliminated
or have coverage under an appropriate NPDES permit issued and approved by the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. When such permit coverage is available,
discharges from off-lot discharging home sewage treatment systems will no
longer be exempt from the requirements of this regulation.
   (b)   Prohibition of Illicit Connections. The construction, use,
maintenance, or continued existence of illegal connections to the MS4 is
prohibited.
      (1)   This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illegal
connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was
permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of
connection.
      (2)   A person is considered to be in violation of this regulation if the
person connects a line conveying illicit discharges to the MS4, or allows such
a connection to continue.
(Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.08 MONITORING OF ILLICIT DISCHARGES AND ILLEGAL CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Establishment of an Illicit Discharge and Illegal Connection
Monitoring Program: As part of its SWMP, the Village shall establish a program
to detect and eliminate illicit discharges and illegal connections to the MS4.
This program shall include the mapping of the MS4, including MS4 outfalls and
home sewage treatment systems; the routine inspection of storm water outfalls
to the MS4, and the systematic investigation of potential residential,
commercial, industrial, and institutional facilities for the sources of any dry
weather flows found as the result of these inspections.
   (b)   Inspection of Residential, Commercial, Industrial, or Institutional
Facilities.
      (1)   The Village shall be permitted to enter and inspect facilities
subject to this regulation as often as may be necessary to determine compliance
with this regulation.
      (2)   The Village shall have the right to set up at facilities subject to
this regulation such devices as are necessary to conduct monitoring and/or
sampling of the facility's storm water discharge, as determined by the Village.
      (3)   The Village shall have the right to require the facility owner/
operator to install monitoring equipment as necessary. This sampling and
monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in safe and proper
operating condition by the facility owner/operator at the owner/operator's
expense. All devices used to measure storm water flow and quality shall be
calibrated by the Village to ensure their accuracy.
      (4)   Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and reasonable
access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed
by the facility's owner/operator at the written or oral request of the Village
and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by
the facility owner/operator.
      (5)   Unreasonable delays in allowing the Village access to a facility
subject to this regulation for the purposes of illicit discharge inspection is
a violation of this regulation.
      (6)   If the Village is refused access to any part of the facility from
which storm water is discharged, and the Village demonstrates probable cause to
believe that there may be a violation of this regulation, or that there is a
need to inspect and/or sample as part of an inspection and sampling program
designed to verify compliance with this regulation or any order issued
hereunder, or to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, the Village
may seek issuance of a search warrant, civil remedies including but not limited
to injunctive relief, and/or criminal remedies from any court of appropriate
jurisdiction.
      (7)   Any costs associated with these inspections may be assessed to the
facility owner/operator. (Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.09 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   Notice of Violation. When the Village finds that a person has violated
a prohibition or failed to meet a requirement of this regulation, the Village
may order compliance by written Notice of Violation. Such notice must specify
the violation and shall be hand delivered, and/or sent by certified mail,
return receipt requested or by regular mail if the certified mail is not
delivered for any reason, to the owner/operator of the facility. Such notice
may require the following actions:
      (1)   The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting;
      (2)   The elimination of illicit discharges or illegal connections;
      (3)   That violating discharges, practices, or operations cease and
desist;
      (4)   The abatement or remediation of storm water pollution or
contamination hazards and the restoration of any affected property; or
      (5)   The implementation of source control or treatment BMP
   (b)   If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is
required, the Notice of Violation shall set forth a deadline within which such
remediation or restoration must be completed. Said Notice shall further advise
that, should the facility owner/operator fail to remediate or restore within
the established deadline, a legal action for enforcement may be initiated.
   (c)   Any person receiving a Notice of Violation must meet compliance
standards within the time established in the Notice of Violation.
   (d)   Administrative Hearing: If any member of the Village administration
makes any adverse decision under the authority vested by this chapter, that
decision may be appealed by any person adversely affected thereby to the
Village Planning and Zoning Commission by sending a letter to the Building
Inspector within ten (10) days of the decision. Planning and Zoning Commission
shall place the matter on the agenda for the next meeting occurring not less
than ten (10) days after receipt of the letter by the Building Inspector. The
Planning and Zoning Commission shall hear the appeal, and make a recommendation
to Council within sixty (60) days of the filing of the letter requesting the
appeal, unless the appellant consents to a longer period of time. In the event
the Planning and Zoning Commission does not decide the issue within sixty (60)
days of the filing of the letter requesting the appeal, and the appellant has
not consented to a longer period of time, the appeal shall be forwarded to
Council for final determination. The decision of Council shall be final within
the Village and may be appealed pursuant to law by any person.
   (e)   Injunctive Relief: It shall be unlawful for any owner/operator to
violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this
regulation pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3709.211. If an owner/operator has violated or
continues to violate the provisions of this regulation, the Village may
petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the owner/
operator from activities that would create further violations or compelling the
owner/operator to perform abatement or remediation of the violation.
(Ord. 2009-12. Passed 8-10-09.)
923.10 REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE.
   The remedies listed in this regulation are not exclusive of any other
remedies available under any applicable federal, state or local law and it is
in the discretion of Village to seek cumulative remedies. (Ord. 2009-12. Passed
10-10-09.)
CHAPTER 925
Storm Sewers
925.01   Storm sewer management.
925.02   Maintenance of ditches, culverts and storm sewers.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Sanitary Sewers - see S.U & P.S. Ch.
929
 
925.01 STORM SEWER MANAGEMENT.
   (a)   Purpose: The purpose of these regulations is to provide for the
health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the Village of New
Middletown through the regulation of modifications to the Village's municipal
separate storm sewer system (MS4).
   (b)   Rules and Regulations: The Village Administrator, in consultation with
the Village Engineer or an engineering firm hired to perform engineering
services on an annual basis for the Village, shall establish uniform rules and
regulations and a uniform permit process to address requests by property owners
in the Village who request authority to install culverts and storm water lines
in the roadside ditches along the Village right of way. Such rules shall
require, among other provisions, that all ditches shall remain open except in
those areas where Class "A" streets are being constructed or Class "B" streets
are being redesigned and reconstructed as Class "A" streets and except in those
circumstances as specifically authorized by the rules and regulations and
approved by the Village Engineer. All culverts or catch basins or storm water
lines shall be installed only in accordance with the rules and regulations, and
the specifications outlined therein, established in accordance with this
section.
   (c)   Permit Required: No person, business, or organization shall install
any culvert, catch basin or storm water pipe of any kind within any portion of
the right of way of any street, in any portion of any ditch which is within the
right of way of any street, or in any part of the Village's municipal separate
storm sewer system (MS4), as defined in Section
923.03 of the Codified Ordinances, without first obtaining a permit from the
Village Administrator. Permits may be issued under this Chapter for
installation of storm sewer pipe within ditches and for closing in ditches
along the streets in the Village only in those areas where Class "A" streets
are being constructed or Class "B" streets are being redesigned and
reconstructed as Class "A" streets and in those circumstances as specifically
authorized by the rules and regulations and approved by the Village Engineer.
The application for a permit shall be on such forms as shall be prescribed by
the Village Administrator and shall be accompanied by a fee of ten dollars
($10.00).
   (d)   Penalty:  
      (1)   Whoever violates any provision of this section or the rules and
regulations established by the Village Administrator under the authority of
this section shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day's violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
      (2)   The Village also may seek any civil remedies including but not
limited to injunctive relief, or may assess the costs incurred by the Village
in enforcing this section or in removing any culverts, catch basins or storm
water lines installed in violation of this section or in violation of the rules
and regulations adopted hereunder against the person, business, or organization
which violates any provision of this section, including the property owner. The
Village shall give five days' notice, by regular mail, to the property owner,
at his or her last known address, to pay the cost incurred by the Village. Such
notice shall be accompanied by a statement of the amount of cost incurred and,
in the event the same is not paid within thirty days after the mailing of such
notice, such amount shall be certified to the County Auditor for collection of
the same as other taxes and assessments are collected. (Ord. 2022-08. Passed 6-
13-22.)
925.02  MAINTENANCE OF DITCHES, CULVERTS AND STORM SEWERS.
   (a)   Maintenance of Ditches:
      (1)   All owners or persons in possession of a lot or parcel of land
abutting roads and highways within the Village are responsible for maintaining
the ditches along such property and keeping such ditches free from obstruction,
including mowing, cutting or destroying or causing to be cut or destroyed any
noxious or poisonous weeds, vines, grasses or other types of vegetation growing
within the ditches, adjacent to such lot or parcel of land. Notwithstanding the
forgoing, the Village will be responsible for digging out any ditches that the
Village determines need dug out.
       (2)   In the event such owner or person in possession of such property
fails to maintain such ditch within five days after written notice sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested or served in accordance with R.C.
731.52, the Village may maintain the ditch and after the work is done, the
Village shall give five days' notice, by regular mail, to the owner of such lot
or parcel of land, at his or her last known address, to pay the cost of such
maintenance. Such notice shall be accompanies by a statement of the amount of
cost incurred and, in the event the same is not paid within thirty days after
the mailing of such notice, such amount shall be certified to the County
Auditor for collection of the same as other taxes and assessments are
collected.
   (b)   Maintenance of Driveway Culverts and Piped Ditches:
      (1)   The Village shall maintain and clean out all drive pipes or
culverts or storm water pipe installed in ditches which are a part of the
Village's municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4).
      (2)   Except as otherwise provided in any rules and regulations adopted
in accordance with Section
925.01(b), in the event it is necessary to replace any driveway culvert, the
cost of such replacement shall be borne by the property owner.
      (3)   Except as otherwise provided in any rules and regulations adopted
in accordance with Section
 925.01(b), in the event it is necessary to dig and replace any existing storm
water pipe installed in ditches which are a part of the Village's MS4, the
Village Administrator, after consultation with the Village Engineer or an
engineering firm hired to perform engineering services on an annual basis for
the Village, shall determine whether to replace such pipe or remove such pipe
and return the affected area to a roadside ditch constructed in accordance with
the Village Ordinances.
         (Ord. 2018-10. Passed 2-11-19.)
CHAPTER 927
Water
927.01   Water delivery fee.
927.02   Water wells.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to provide and regulate water system - see Ohio R. C. 715.08, 717.01,
743.01
Water pollution - see Ohio R. C. 715.08, 743.25
Compulsory water connections - see Ohio R. C. 729.06, 743.23
Weekly deposit of water works money collected - see Ohio R. C. 743.06
Fluoridation - see Ohio R. C. 6111.13
Water pollution control - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 6111
Water supply - see OAC 4101:2-51-37
Backflow - see OAC 4101:2-51-38
927.01 WATER DELIVERY FEE.
   (a)   Definitions.
      (1)   "Customer" means an individual or entity who receives delivery of
water and/or water services from the Water Works System and to whom a water
bill is issued or who is otherwise responsible for payment for the use and/or
receipt of water and/or water services from the Water Works System.
      (2)   "Extraterritorial Property" means any Property located outside the
territorial limits of the Village and within the area served by the Village
Water Works System, and bounded and described as follows:
Beginning at the southern right of way of E. Calla Road at its intersection
with Unity Road, extending east to the present Aqua Service Area boundary line,
following that line until it intersects with E. Calla Road east of Rapp Road,
then following the southern right-of-way of E. Calla Road to the Ohio/
Pennsylvania line; then extending south along the state line to the northern
right-of way line of South Range Road, and following said right-of-way line
west to the present Aqua service area boundary; then running along said
boundary north until it intersects with the northern right of way line of E.
Middletown Road; then west along said E. Middletown Road right of way to its
intersection with Unity Road; then north along the eastern right of way of
Unity Road to the place of beginning.
      (3)   "Non-resident Customer" means a Customer who resides and/or owns
Extraterritorial Property.
      (4)   "Property" means any parcel of real property to which water and/or
water services from the Water Works System are delivered or provided.
      (5)   "Village" means the Village of New Middletown, Ohio.
      (6)   "Water Works System" means all water distribution and transmission
facilities owned or hereafter acquired by the Village used and useful for the
distribution and transmission of a potable water supply, including, but not
limited to, any and all water mains, water lines, water storage facilities,
pumps and booster stations, valves, hydrants, service lines and meters,
including, but not limited to, any distribution and transmission facilities
leased to an Ohio public utility corporation.
   (b)   Purpose. The purpose of this Section is to distribute the cost of
replacements and/or improvements to the Water Works System equitably between
(1) Village Customers and/or Property owners, who contribute to or otherwise
pay for replacements and/or improvements to the Water Works System through
payment of taxes to the Village and (2) Non-resident Customers who enjoy the
delivery of water from the Water Works System but do not contribute to or share
the cost of replacements and/or improvements to such delivery system via
payment of taxes Justification for imposition of this fee is that residents of
the Village are assessed and pay to the Village certain taxes, a portion of
which is used by the Village to cover the cost of replacements and/or
improvements to the Water Works System The delivery fee assessed to Non-
resident Customers enables Non-resident Customers to share a portion of the
cost of replacements and/or improvements to the water lines which deliver water
to such Non-resident Customers.
   (c)   Authority. Pursuant to the powers granted to municipalities by the
Ohio Constitution as well as Ohio Revised Code Section 743.04, for the purpose
of paying the expenses of conducting and managing the Village's Water Works
System, including operating expenses and the costs of permanent improvements,
the Village Fiscal Officer may assess and collect a water rent or charge of
sufficient amount and in such manner as determined to be most equitable from
all tenements and premises supplied with water.
   (d)   Establishment of Delivery Fee. An annual water delivery fee shall be
charged to all Non-resident Customers. The amount of such delivery fee shall be
determined by Village Council and shall be based on the reasonable cost
incurred by the Village for replacements and/or improvements to the Water Works
System, the expected cost of future replacements and/or improvements to the
Water Works System, and a reasonable reserve for future replacements and/or
improvements.
   (e)   Collection of Delivery Fee. Each calendar year, either the Village or
any agent of the Village or individual or entity designated by the Village
shall send a statement to each Non-resident Customer, which shall set forth the
delivery fee and instructions for making timely payment of the delivery fee.
Each Non-resident Customer shall make payment in accordance with the
instructions set forth in the statement. The statement may be included with or
on the regular monthly bill or statement for that month received by the Non-
resident Customer for its monthly consumption of water.
   (f)   Failure to Timely Pay Delivery Fee. When the delivery fee is not paid
when due, any Village Fiscal Officer may take any action as such official deems
fit pursuant to Ohio Revised Code 743.04, as amended, or any other statute in
effect at the time, as the case may be.
(Ord. 2013-10. Passed 2-10-14.)
927.02 WATER WELLS.
   No new wells shall be permitted to be dug within the Village limits, except
as authorized by the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 728-81. Passed 11-15-79.)

TITLE FIVE - Other Public Services TITLE FIVE - Other Public Services
Chap.
941. Parks.
 
 
 
CHAPTER 941
Parks
941.01   General rules and regulations.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 955.19 et seq.
Power to regulate speed limits in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
 
941.01 GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
(a)   Fires.  
      (1)   No person shall start or maintain a fire on Village or Park lands,
except small fires in grills for cooking purposes or fires in fireplaces.
      (2)   No person shall leave a fire that he or she has started. All fires
started shall be put out by the person starting them before leaving the area.
      (3)   Any person discarding a lighted match, cigarette or cigar shall
completely extinguish and dispose of it in a proper receptacle.
   (b)   Preservation of Property and Plant Material.
      (1)   No person shall in any way damage, deface, destroy or remove any
part of a Village or Park owned facility, sign, equipment, or other property.
      (2)   No person shall damage, destroy, deface or remove any part of any
tree, flower, shrub or other vegetation.
   (c)   Alcoholic Beverages, Drugs, Opiates, Intoxicants, or Hallucinatory
Substances.
      (1)   No person shall consume, possess, distribute or offer for sale any
alcoholic beverage within the Park.
      (2)   No person shall use, possess, distribute or offer for sale any
drugs, opiates, marijuana or hallucinatory substances within the Park.
      (3)   No person shall be under the influence of the substances stated in
(c)(1) and (c)(2) while within the Park.
   (d)   Gambling and Games of Chance. No person shall organize, conduct or
participate in games of chance involving money (Bingo, Poker, etc.) in any form
within the Park.
   (e)   Garbage, Yard Waste and Foreign Materials.
      (1)   No person shall discard or dispose of, on Park property, any
household garbage, yard waste or foreign materials generated outside of the
Park.
      (2)   Refuse, garbage and other residue of a picnic or activity shall be
deposited in receptacles provided for such purposes.
   (f)   Speed Limit. The speed limit for all motor vehicles using Village or
Park drives is five miles per hour (5 mph).
   (g)   Animals.
      (1)   Dogs, cats and other household pets are permitted on Park property
only if the animal is controlled at all times, either in a cage or on a leash
no longer than six feet. Dogs and cats are not permitted on playgrounds, picnic
areas, and flower beds or in buildings, the gazebo or pavilions.
      (2)   Dog, cat or household pet droppings must be removed from the
following Park facilities by the person in control of the animal: drives,
parking lots, walkways, trails or within ten (10) feet of the aforementioned
facilities.
      (3)   No person shall abandon any animal on the Park property
   (h)   Snowmobiles, All-terrain Vehicles, Dirt Bikes. No person shall operate
a snowmobile, all-terrain vehicle, dirt bike or any other off-road vehicle on
Park property.
   (i)   Hours of Closing. The Park shall be open from 8:00 a.m. until dark,
unless prior reservations are made for use of the Park after dark. No person
shall be on Park lands when the park is closed except Village employees on
duty.
   (j)   Rollerskates, Skate Boards, Rollerblades and Bicycles. No person is
permitted to rollerskate, skateboard, rollerblade or bicycle on playgrounds,
tennis courts, park drives, walkways, paths or parking lots. This activity is
restricted to the skate park.
   (k)   Walkways and Paths.
      (1)   No person shall drive a motorized vehicle on any walkway or paths
other than motorized wheelchairs or similar equipment. Vehicles are restricted
to paved roadways or drives and designated parking areas.
      (2)   The walkways and paths and the other areas of the Park shall be
closed from dusk to 8:00 a.m., year round. No person shall be in the Park
during these hours except Village employees on duty.
   (l)   Commercial Enterprises.
      (1)   No person shall offer for sale any article, privilege, service or
subscription on Park or Village lands unless approved by the Mayor or Village
Council President.
      (2)   No person shall solicit collections or donations nor beg and hawk
for any purpose on Park property unless approved by the Mayor or Village
Council President.
   (m)   Reservation Rules and Regulations.
      (1)   Persons holding a reservation for a Park pavilion, gazebo, or
facility shall not have use of the facility where said use exceeds the number
of hours stated per the reservation permit. The hours reserved shall include
set-up and clean-up time.
      (2)   Persons not holding a reservation for a Park pavilion, gazebo, or
facility shall be permitted to use such facility, but persons holding a
reservation shall have priority over persons without reservations.
      (3)   Each person wishing to reserve a park pavilion or gazebo shall fill
out a reservation permit form and shall pay a reservation fee of seventy-five
dollars ($75.00) for the larger pavilion, fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
smaller pavilion, and twenty-five dollars ($25,00) for the gazebo. Each person
reserving one of the pavilions or the gazebo shall be responsible for ensuring
that the pavilion or gazebo and park facilities are not damaged and are left
clean and free of trash and debris following such permit holder's use of the
pavilion or gazebo.
      (4)   Persons holding reservation permits are responsible for the
physical condition of the facility reserved and overseeing the conduct of
persons in attendance. Any damage to the facility as a result of said
reservation shall be the responsibility of the person holding the reservation
permit.
      (5)   No person shall transfer tables and chairs, owned by the Village,
from one area to another except with the permission of the Mayor or Village
Council President.
      (6)   No person shall misuse and/or abuse any facility of the Park. Any
violator will receive a written letter governing and/or restricting future
reservations.
   (n)   Firearms, Fireworks, Explosives, Bows and Arrows.
      (1)   No person shall carry, possess, discharge or have under their
control firearms of any type, air, gas, or pellet guns, sling shots, fireworks
or explosives on or into Park or Village lands except with the permission of
the Mayor or Village Council or the Village Police Chief.
      (2)   No person shall carry, possess, discharge or have under their
control a paint ball gun or other similar device on or into Park or Village
lands.
   (o)   Disorderly Conduct. No person shall recklessly cause inconvenience,
annoyance, or alarm to another, by doing any of the following:
      (1)   Engaging in fighting, in threatening harm to persons or property,
or in violent or turbulent behavior.
      (2)   Making unreasonable noise or offensively coarse utterance, gesture,
or display, or communicating unwarranted and grossly abusive language to any
person.
      (3)   Insulting, taunting, or challenging another, under circumstances in
which such conduct is likely to provoke a violent response.
      (4)   Hindering or preventing the movement of persons on a public street,
road, highway, or right-of-way, or to, from, within, or upon public or private
property, so as to interfere with the rights of others, and by any act which
serves no lawful and reasonable purpose of the offender.
      (5)   Creating a condition which is physically offensive to persons or
which presents a risk of physical harm to persons or property, by any act which
serves no lawful and reasonable purpose of the offender.
   (p)   Parking. No person shall park a motor vehicle, trailer, motorcycle or
any other vehicle on the lands of the Park or Village except in places
designated by the Village for such purposes.
   (q)   Other Regulations. In addition to the General Rules and Regulations,
Park visitors are also subject to the Rules and Regulations of playgrounds and
other Park or Village facilities and activities.
   (r)   No Smoking. No person shall carry, possess, use or have under their
control a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other similar object within any
building or indoor meeting room of the Village.
   (s)   Penalties. Whoever violates any of these General Rules and Regulations
is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars; for each subsequent offense such person is of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than $500.00 or
imprisoned not more than sixty days or both.
(Ord. 2018-03. Passed 2-12-18.)

CHAPTER 1101
Administration
